title: DECAF Score for Acute Exacerbation of COPD
description: Predicts in-hospital mortality in acute COPD exacerbation using five clinical variables: Dyspnoea, Eosinopenia, Consolidation, Acidaemia, and atrial Fibrillation.

parameters.name: emrcd_dyspnea
parameters.description: Extended MRC Dyspnea Scale (eMRCD) - functional status assessment

parameters.name: atrial_fibrillation
parameters.description: Atrial fibrillation on ECG or history

parameters.name: patient_age
parameters.description: Patient age in years (for clinical context, ≥35 years required for score validity)

parameters.name: smoking_history
parameters.description: Smoking history for clinical context (≥10 pack-years required for score validity)

result.name: decaf_assessment
result.description: DECAF score with mortality risk assessment and clinical management recommendations

ranges.interpretation: In-hospital mortality risk 0-1.5%. Routine ward-based management is appropriate. Standard COPD exacerbation care with bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and supportive care.
In-hospital mortality risk 5.4%. Use clinical judgment regarding disposition and level of care. Consider closer monitoring and assessment for complications.
In-hospital mortality risk 15.3-50%. Consider escalation of care (HDU/ICU) versus palliative care discussions. These patients warrant intensive monitoring and aggressive management.
ranges.recommendation: Consider escalation of care vs. palliative care

clinical_applications: In-hospital mortality prediction for acute COPD exacerbation
Risk stratification for disposition and level of care decisions
Early identification of patients requiring intensive monitoring
Supporting discussions about goals of care and palliative options
Quality improvement and standardization of COPD exacerbation management
Clinical decision support for emergency department and hospital medicine
Research stratification and outcome prediction in COPD studies

low_risk: Discharge planning and outpatient follow-up arrangement
intermediate_risk: Close clinical monitoring and frequent reassessment
Consider higher level of nursing care or step-down unit
Early assessment for respiratory failure and need for ventilation
Consider early mobilization and respiratory therapy
high_risk: Strong consideration for HDU/ICU level care
Early assessment for non-invasive or invasive ventilation
Aggressive medical management with close monitoring
Palliative care consultation for goals of care discussion
Consider early family meetings and advance directive discussions

references: Steer J, Gibson J, Bourke SC. The DECAF Score: predicting hospital mortality in exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Thorax. 2012;67(11):970-976. doi: 10.1136/thoraxjnl-2012-202103.

Echevarria C, Steer J, Heslop-Marshall K, et al. Validation of the DECAF score to predict hospital mortality in acute exacerbations of COPD. Thorax. 2016;71(2):133-140. doi: 10.1136/thoraxjnl-2015-207775.

Zhou M, Chen Y, Yang M, et al. DECAF score as a mortality predictor for acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ Open. 2021;11(2):e044923. doi: 10.1136/bmjopen-2020-044923.

Nafae RM, Embarak S, Gad DM. Value of the DECAF score in predicting hospital mortality in patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease admitted to Zagazig University Hospitals, Egypt. Egypt J Chest Dis Tuberc. 2015;64(1):35-40. doi: 10.1016/j.ejcdt.2014.07.006.
formula: DECAF Score = Dyspnoea (0-2 points) + Eosinopenia (0-1 point) + Consolidation (0-1 point) + Acidaemia (0-1 point) + atrial Fibrillation (0-1 point)
notes: Score applies only to patients ≥35 years old with acute COPD exacerbation
Requires ≥10 pack-year smoking history for validity
Should only be used in hospitalized patients, not outpatient or stable COPD
Extended MRC Dyspnea Scale assesses functional limitation due to breathlessness
Consolidation must be present on chest X-ray imaging
Acidemia requires arterial blood gas measurement with pH <7.30
Atrial fibrillation can be current or historical
Higher scores (3-6) warrant consideration of escalated care or palliative discussions
Score has been validated across multiple international populations
Superior prognostic accuracy compared to other COPD severity scores

validation.population: Hospitalized patients ≥35 years with acute COPD exacerbation and ≥10 pack-year smoking history
validation.evidence_basis: Derived and validated from UK prospective cohort studies, externally validated internationally
validation.clinical_utility: Validated tool for mortality prediction and care escalation decisions in acute COPD exacerbation
